title: Climate_Change.BBC_Radio_documentaries.ogg.radioCat
description:
Climate Change

Three BBC Radio documentaries

1 Can Americ Go Green
---------------------
1.1. The Addiction to Oil:  Can car makers to kick the oil habit and &#039;green&#039; their industry?  Terry Tamminen and Bob Semple talk about how vested interests killed off electric cars.  

1.2. Corporate Responsibility:  General Electric has gone green and sees its future prosperity tied to developing green technologies, taking the bold stance of publicly recognising global warming and its links to human activity.

1.3. How Green is Your Valley:  Laura Trevelyan considers the size of the US&#039;s carbon footprint in relation to urban sprawl and the work of the "New Urbanists" to create greener places for Americans to live in.


2 Inside the Climate Change Talks
---------------------------------
2.1 The USA and Emmissions:  The US didn&#039;t ratify the Kyoto agreement to cut CO2 emissions, and the White House is still resistant to binding targets. But American public opinion is shifting.

2.2 Islands - Victims of Climate Change:  The latest IPCC report identifies low lying island states as the victims of climate change, yet their emissions are negligible. These nations say they struggle to get their voices heard.

2.3 India and the USA - an &#039;Unholy&#039; Alliance:  The US is saying they will only sign up to binding targets if India and other big emitters do. But India says it is emissions are negligible in per capita terms, and tackling poverty through development is the priority. Two nations in an "unholy" alliance, holding out against massive pressure.

2.4. In Search of a New Kyoto:  In a special BBC WS One Planet debate, we bring together four people at the heart of their governments&#039; response to climate change -from the USA, Indonesia, Brazil and the UK.


3 Carbon Economy
----------------
3.1 Carbon Trading:  An investigation into the effectiveness of carbon trading through the EU Emissions Trading Scheme

3.2 Carbon Capture:  The science and engineering behond clean carbon power generation schemes, by carbon capture and storage
